This is distinct from the treatment in Vulcan version 3.0 which included spatial and temporal proxies at the sub-county and sub-annual scales. This change was dictated by the limited gain in accuracy to the labor involved in further downscaling the nonpoint and point output for this sector only. The Vulcan version 4.0 nonroad nonpoint emissions rely on the output of Vulcan version 3.0, further scaling the 2010–2015 emissions to the longer time series up to 2022. The emissions have separate entries for natural gas and petroleum emissions.Point emissions are ingested from the point processing for this sector and are hence, at the facility-scale.To generate a complete 2010–2022 time series based on the Vulcan version 3.0 output, the SEDS dataset for state-scale natural gas and petroleum nonroad consumption is rescaled as relative to 2014 only. This is done by availing of the ratio of the total US nonroad NEI 2017 to NEI 2014 FFCO2 emissions. This national ratio is combined with the nonroad/state/fuel SEDS ratios in the 2016–2022 time period to establish ratios in the entire timespan that are relative to 2014 only. These are then applied to arrive at a complete 2010–2022 time series of county nonroad FFCO2 emissions for natural gas and petroleum separately.Commercial marine vesselsCommercial marine vessel (CMV) emissions include vessels directly or indirectly involved in commerce or military activity. The emissions encompass maneuvering, hoteling, cruise and reduced speed zone travel and are specific to geographically located ports and shipping lanes that extend 12 nautical miles from the U.S. shoreline. FFCO2 emissions associated with U.S. commercial marine vessel (CMV) activity is characterized from the processing of the 2014/2017 NEI nonpoint source data. It is critical to note that the 2014 nonpoint CMV FFCO2 emissions have common IDs allowing for the emissions to be linked to a U.S. CMV geographic basemap reflecting both port and shipping lane spatial information. However, the 2017 NEI CMV nonpoint records have IDs that have no partner in the geographic spatialization files. Hence, the spatial pattern determined for the 2010-2015 time period (based on NEI2014 and its linkage to the CMV shapefile) was carried forward from 2016 to 2022 based on the relative nonpoint county CMV FFCO2 totals.In the instance that no spatial entity is identified for an emission record, a simple spatial alternative is employed whereby all the unlinked port emissions (underway) are summed within a county and evenly distributed to the shapes that are identified within that county (either ports or shipping lanes).The CMV sector has no data allowing for the designation of hourly time structure. Hence, the emissions are temporally invariant over all hours of the year.Cement productionCO2 is emitted from cement manufacturing as a result of fuel combustion and as process-derived emissions56. The process-derived CO2 emissions result from the chemical process that converts limestone to calcium oxide and CO2. This occurs during clinker production (clinker is the raw material for cement which is produced by grinding the clinker material). Unlike the Vulcan version 3.0 approach in which only the stoichiometric emissions were calculated and it was assumed that the emissions due to fuel combustion were captured in the NEI point source reporting, Vulcan version 4.0 calculates the fuel combustion component directly from clinker production and removes any records from the NEI point source reporting related to the fuel combustion component of cement production.The stochiometric CO2 emissions remain identical to the methodological approach taken in Vulcan version 3.0. The calculation of FFCO2 due to fuel consumption in cement facilities is based on the generation of an emission factor based on the production of clinker at each cement producing facility (tC/kt clinker). This emission factor is a US mean value and derived from data provided by the United States Geological Survey National Minerals Information Center Minerals Yearbook (https://www.usgs.gov/centers/national-minerals-information-center/cement-statistics-and-information). This provides the total U.S. clinker production and the fuel consumed, by fuel type, to generate the clinker.UncertaintyThe uncertainty estimation method in Vulcan version 4.0 remains unchanged from the Vulcan version 3.0. A succinct review is as follows:For the reported CO emissions, a critical element of the input data, an uncertainty value of ±12.8% was used. We interpret this as a 95% confidence interval given that this is estimated from a measure of difference by Gately and Hutyra57 in the residential sector (which dominates the nonpoint source emissions). We adopt this value and apply it to each nonpoint CO emission reporting record in the 2014 and 2017 NEI, used as county‐scale input to the Vulcan nonpoint estimation. For the emission factor (EF) uncertainty, the CO and CO2 EFs were adjusted in combination such that the outcome achieves the “hi” (upper) and “lo” (lower) confidence interval (CI), respectively. An uncertainty of ±20% is applied to both the default and self‐reported CO EFs regardless of fuel type. An exception to this is for the blast furnace gas and coke oven gas fuel types in which the adjustment is ±35%. The CO EF adjustment is based on estimates of the range found in the WebFIRE EF database and the self‐reported CO emission factors reported in the NEI. The CO2 EF uncertainty for coal is derived from the work of Quick58 while uncertainty for petroleum fuels and natural gas are derived from USEPA Greenhouse Gas Inventory, Annex 259. These emission factor uncertainties are applied at the county spatial‐scale but specific to the individual source classification code (SCC).These uncertainties are propagated through all subsequent steps such as the allocation to subcounty spatial scales and subannual temporal scales. No further increase or adjustment to the uncertainty is performed in those sectors where additional downscaling, in space (from county to Census block) or time (from annual to hourly), is made. Furthermore, the final uncertainty for a given spatial aggregation (e.g., county, state) will vary depending upon the mix of SCC‐specific emissions in the aggregations.Point source uncertainty is applied to the reported CO emissions, the CO EF, and the CO2 EF. For the reported CO emissions, an uncertainty value of ±7.8% is used as a 95% confidence interval. This uncertainty value was reported by Gately & Hutyra57 for the industrial and commercial sectors (which dominate the point sources) and based on a state‐scale difference between Anthropogenic Carbon Emission System (ACES) and EIA state industrial + commercial fuel consumption. We adopt this uncertainty value and apply it to each point CO emission reporting record in the 2014 and 2017 NEI record, used as input to the Vulcan point estimation. For the default EF uncertainty, the CO and CO2 EFs were adjusted in combination following the same procedure described in the nonpoint source section and the same percentage numerical boundaries described there were used. For the records that use the EPA WebFIRE CO EFs, an uncertainty value of ±20% is used for the 95% CI bounds sourced as noted for the nonpoint EFs.These uncertainties are propagated through all subsequent steps and the final uncertainty for a given spatial aggregation (e.g., county, state) will vary depending upon the mix of SCC‐specific emissions in the aggregations. Point data, being already quantified with uncertainty at the ultimate spatial resolution, requires no additional uncertainty adjustment in space. However, application of the hourly time resolution from the original annual time resolution is accompanied by no further increase or adjustment to the uncertainty. This acknowledges that while there is likely an increase in uncertainty at the hourly scale, there is no objective information available to quantify this.A previous study23 found that one fifth of U.S. power plants had monthly FFCO2 emission differences exceeding−6.4%/ + 6.8% for the year 2009. We conservatively consider the quintile value (the positive and negative tails) as a one‐sigma value and ±13% as a 95% CI boundary value. This uncertainty is applied at the facility spatial scale. Since over 90% of the FFCO2 emissions in the electricity production sector are quantified at the facility/hourly space/time scale, no further adjustment to the uncertainty is made.The uncertainty in the onroad sector was estimated at ±7.1% for a presumed 1‐sigma uncertainty at the 1 km2/annual resolution. Here, we have assigned ±14.2% to the 95% CI boundaries for all road types. The uncertainty values used are derived from Gately and Hutyra57 which, in turn, references Gately et al.60 and Mendoza et al.61. These uncertainties are applied at the county/annual space/time scale and are propagated through all subsequent steps such as the allocation to sub‐county road segments and subannual temporal scales. No increase in the uncertainty is made during the allocation steps.Nonroad records other than those derived from the point source data files (which follow the point source uncertainty estimation described in the point source section) are assigned a 95% CI boundary of ±3.8% for the FFCO2 emission value. This was derived from examination of the range of carbon content and fuel density uncertainties as outlined in United States Environmental Protection Agency59, Annex 2, page A‐86.The uncertainty in the airport sector is derived from the point source processing as described previously (magnitude and EF‐based uncertainty) except that the FFCO2 EFs are specific to the mix of aviation fuels associated with the emission records. These uncertainties are propagated through all subsequent steps and the final uncertainty for a given spatial aggregation (e.g., airport, county, state) will vary depending upon the mix of airplane classes and fuels in the aggregations.The uncertainty for the railroad and CMV emissions are directly inherited from the uncertainty estimation described for the point and nonpoint source processing, respectively. The only difference is related to the CO magnitude uncertainty (±3.8% for rail, ±10.0% for CMV) which was derived from examination of the range of carbon content and fuel density values. As per the description of uncertainty application in the point and nonpoint processing, these uncertainties are applied at scale from an individual point location to the county spatial scale. The uncertainties are propagated through all subsequent steps such as the allocation to the railroad and CMV polyline/polygon maps and sub‐annual temporal scales. Additional uncertainty associated with downscaling in space (i.e., from county to polylines/polygons) or time (from annual to hourly) are not included in the final uncertainty estimate.The uncertainty in the cement emissions sector is currently prescribed as ± 10% for the 95% CI. This estimate uses a comparison between the facility‐scale sum of clinker production in a state and the United States Geological Survey (USGS) state throughput (estimated from the capacity factor and capacity). The mean percentage difference across all states and multistate aggregates was 9.8%, which was rounded to 10% and interpreted as a 95% CI value.Data RecordsThe complete annual 1 km2 sector-specific FFCO2 emissions for the years 2010-2022 are published on Zenodo62 (https://zenodo.org/records/15446748). There are two domains: 1) the contiguous United States (CONUS), 2) Alaska. The archive consists of 21 zip files, 2 excel files, and one.pdf file (the readme). The excel files consist of a single county aggregate and single state aggregate file. The remaining 21 zip files contain 13 individual annual files (in GeoTIFF format) for a given sector and domain (Alaska versus CONUS). Hence, there are 11 CONUS zipped files (10 sectors, 1 total), 10 Alaska zipped files (9 sectors - no cement sector, 1 total)). However, evaluation of the FFCO2 emissions at more aggregate scales can be accomplished via two different methods. The first is to compare the emissions to independent estimation using atmospheric 14CO2, a unique tracer for fossil fuel CO2. A study by Basu et al. estimating national FFCO2 from atmospheric observations of 14CO2 was performed, using the Vulcan version 3.0 results64. No equivalent study has been made using Vulcan version 4.0 as of the current date. In the comparison using Vulcan version 3.0 for the year 2010, the national/annual-scale Vulcan version 3.0 FFCO2 emissions (adjusted for system boundaries in Basu et al.) and the atmospheric‐derived estimate agreed to within 1.4% (Vulcan > Basu). Vulcan version 4.0 FFCO2 emissions (adjusted similarly) in the year 2010 is 1599.5 tC or −4.7% less than Vulcan version 3.0. Hence, Vulcan version 4.0 differs from the Basu et al. atmospheric 14CO2 inversion by 3.3% (Vulcan < Basu). in the year 2010.The other means by which to evaluate the Vulcan FFCO2 emissions data product is via comparison to other activity-based estimates in the US. Detailed comparison between the Vulcan version 3.0 and the U.S. EPA national inventory was performed and after adjustment for system boundaries found to be 3.2% different in the year 2011 (Vulcan > EPA)63. The EPA now publishes state-scale, sector-specific estimates of CO2 emissions facilitating comparison at a finer resolution than the national comparison performed previously65. In order to ensure definitional consistency, the Vulcan railroad, airport, commercial marine vessels, and onroad sectors are combined to compare to EPAs “Transport” sector. Each of the comparable sectors have R2 values exceeding 0.97 and slope coefficients greater than 0.87 (the electricity production sector) and less than 1.15 (the transport sector). Atypical warming pattern of strong 2023-24 El Niño boosts global temperatures to new 1.5 °C record
                    Ning Jiang1, Congwen Zhu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3663-44811, Michael J. McPhaden 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8423-58052, Zeng-Zhen Hu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8485-34003, Tao Lian 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7438-41104, Chen Zhou 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-1489-51435 & …Deliang Chen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0288-56186 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 6, Article number: 1012 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric dynamicsClimate changePhysical oceanography

AbstractDuring the 2023-24 El Niño, the July 2023–June 2024 average global mean surface temperature peaked at 1.58 °C above pre-industrial levels, associated with a record 0.36 °C year-over-year rise. Here we use statistical models and a Green’s Function method to explore the causes for this rise. We show that sea surface temperature accounts for ~92% of the interannual warming, highlighting the critical role of El Niño diversity. Unlike typical El Niños, dual tropical Pacific warming centers in 2023-24 and an eastward-extended North Atlantic jet stream synergistically amplified sea surface temperatures across tropical basins, accelerating the pace of global warming. From an energy balance perspective, ocean heat content accumulated during the preceding La Niña and a continuous increase in absorbed shortwave radiation over the ocean drove sea surface temperature rise. Accelerated warming may push the climate system closer to critical tipping points, emphasizing the need for enhanced monitoring, mitigation, and adaptation strategies.

IntroductionAfter rising to a record-breaking level in 2023, global mean surface temperature (GMST) in 2024 reached an unprecedented new record, with an increase of 1.55 °C above pre-industrial levels1,2.Notably, 2024 marked the first time that GMST surpassed the 1.5 °C threshold for an entire calendar year1, resulting in widespread extreme weather and climate disasters3,4. Indeed, by the end of February 2024, the 12-month rolling average GMST had already exceeded 1.5 °C (Supplementary Fig. 1). As per the Paris Climate Agreement5, if this threshold is exceeded for multiple decades or longer, it could indicate a new era fraught with heightened risks from dangerous climate change3,6,7,8, underscoring the critical need for accelerated climate action1,3,4.Understanding the factors responsible for the accelerated rise in GMST is essential for crafting effective mitigation and adaptation strategies9. GMST variations stem from both external forcing (e.g., greenhouse gases and anthropogenic aerosols) and natural climate variability10,11,12,13. Among these, El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO) dominates year-to-year climate variation10,14, exerting distinct impacts on GMST during its warm (El Niño) and cold (La Niña) phases. During La Niña, subsurface ocean heat accumulates in the tropical western Pacific; during El Niño, elevated sea surface temperatures (SST) enhance air-sea heat fluxes, releasing oceanic heat to the atmosphere. This amplifies tropical atmospheric heating and accelerates GMST rise as happened in 2015–1615. Conversely, persistent eastern Pacific cooling can lead to a slowdown or hiatus in global warming, as witnessed during 1998–201316.Following a rare three-year (2020–23) La Niña17, the 2023-24 El Niño contributed to the consecutive years of record-breaking GMST in 2023 and 202418. Given the delay between El Niño emergence and the GMST response, and considering that ENSO events typically peak in November-January19, we define ENSO-years in this study as spanning from July to the following June. The average GMST in ENSO-year 2024 (July 2023-June 2024 average) reached a record high of 1.58 °C (Fig. 1a), associated with an unprecedented interannual increment (ΔGMST) of 0.36 °C relative to ENSO-year 2023 (Fig. 1b). Here, the symbol Δ denotes the change in a variable, specifically referring to the interannual change between two consecutive ENSO-years (i.e., \({\Delta {{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2024}={{{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2024}-{{{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2023}\)).Fig. 1: Observed and modeled GMST and ΔGMST variations.The annual means for ENSO-years refer to the annual averages calculated from July to the following June. a Observed GMST anomalies (°C), relative to 1851–1900 climatology, during the period of 1881–2024. Gray shading marks the 95% confidence interval. b Observed and modeled ΔGMST variations from 1882 to 2024. The symbol Δ denotes the change in a variable, specifically referring to the interannual change between two consecutive ENSO years (i.e., \({\Delta {{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2024}={{{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2024}-{{{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2023}\)). Light blue shading in (b) represents the spread in the model’s ensemble results, while the dark blue line (dot) indicates the ensemble mean. In (a) and (b), red open circles indicate the El Niño years (1983, 1998, 2016, and 2024). The blue dots represent the modeled GMST and ΔGMST values for ENSO-year 2024. c The probability distributions of the bias of the model (see Methods) are derived from the difference between the model’s ensemble outputs and the observations presented in (b) during the period from ENSO-year 1881 to 2023 (gray shading) and ENSO-year 2024 (blue shading), respectively. The modeled values in (b,c) are obtained from the GMST forecast model.Full size imageThe 2023-24 El Niño, measured by tropical eastern Pacific SST, was less intense than historic extremes (1982–83, 1997–98, and 2015–16), yet the associated ΔGMST far exceeded that of past episodes. The mechanisms behind this striking discrepancy and the unprecedented ΔGMST are not completely understood, underscoring the need for further investigation.In this study, we identify the potential factors that contributed to the unprecedented ΔGMST during the 2023–24 El Niño event. The results reveal the decisive role of SST in elevating GMST and underscore the synergistic effects of the 2023–24 El Niño across the tropical oceans.ResultsObservations and model results of GMST in 2024Since the 1970s, GMST has exhibited a consistent warming trend (Fig. 1a), largely driven by anthropocentric forcing20,21. Nevertheless, the warming rates calculated over shorter intervals have shown considerable fluctuations, due to the intrinsic variability inherent in the climate system on annual to decadal timescales10,15,16,22,23,24. On inter-annual timescales, El Niño events in particular, especially extremes such as in 1982-83, 1997-98, and 2015-16, lead to notable spikes in GMST14 (red open circles in Fig. 1a, b).Considering various factors (Supplementary Fig. 2), we have implemented a simple yet effective physically-based forecast model for annual-mean GMST variations. The model, named GMST forecast model (Eq. (1–2)), can effectively describe ΔGMST during ENSO-years10. The predictors consist of greenhouse gas emissions, ENSO influences, stratospheric sulfate aerosols produced by volcanoes, and the damping rate of the climate system10,15. Among these predictors, the impact of ENSO is measured by the annual mean TNINO index, which is an average of SST anomalies in the region 160°E–90°W and 5°S–5°N (dashed black rectangle in Fig. 2a), calculated from July to June10,15. When the observed predictor values prior to 2024 are input into the model, the model can accurately hindcast ΔGMST (Fig. 1b) with a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of approximately 0.07 °C (Fig. 1c)10.Fig. 2: Observed and GSFM modeled global surface temperature variations for ENSO-year 2024.a Observed and c modeled anomalies of SST and LAT for ENSO-year 2024, relative to 1951–1980 climatology. White lines denote the 1.4 °C and 1.7 °C contours in the tropical Pacific, highlighting the spatial patterns. The regions with record-breaking heating are marked with blue dots. The same color scale is applied to both (a) and (c). b,d are the same as (a,c), but for ΔSST and ΔLAT, respectively. e The explained variances of observed ΔSST and ΔLAT by the GSFM (shading) and ENSO (doted for exceeding 20%). f The model bias for ENSO-year 2024 relative to the observations, along with its normalized value (contours for exceeding 1 standard deviation) derived from the period of 1882−2023 (see Method). All years are ENSO-years, defined by the July–June time frame. The white spots in (c–f) are due to data gaps in GISTEMP.Full size imageGiven the potential for extreme heat associated with the 2023–24 El Niño event, we published a forecast of GMST for ENSO-year 2024 using this model, which includes estimated values of the predictors10 (Supplementary Fig. 2). Under an El Niño scenario of moderate or stronger amplitude (Supplementary Fig. 3), characterized by a TNINO index greater than 0.6 °C, GMST was projected to be in the range of 1.30 to 1.47 °C above pre-industrial levels, with a 90% likelihood of surpassing historical records10. However, even the upper boundary of the prediction range was lower than the observed values.Compared to observations, the estimated values of all predictors—greenhouse gases, aerosols, and El Niño intensity—were within reasonable ranges (Supplementary Fig. 2). The spread in GMST predictions primarily arises from the uncertainties in estimating El Niño intensity (Supplementary Fig. 3)10. Notably, the observed TNINO index was far lower than the historical extreme values (Supplementary Fig. 2c). When incorporating the actual observed predictors in ENSO-year 2024 into the GMST forecast model, the estimated ΔGMST is only 0.16 °C. This stands in striking contrast to the observed ΔGMST of 0.36 °C, which substantially exceeded all previous records (Fig. 1b). This bias obviously deviated from the distribution of historical errors (Fig. 1c), suggesting that the GMST forecast model was inadequate for predicting the extreme ΔGMST in ENSO-year 2024. Given the model’s good historical performance, this notable underestimation of ΔGMST not only exposes the complexity of GMST changes but also suggests the distinctiveness of this specific ENSO-year.Observed and modeled spatial distribution of surface temperature in 2024 ENSO-yearTo predict the spatial distribution of surface temperature, including SST and land air temperature (LAT), we have extended the GMST forecast model to encompass each 2° × 2° grid point across the globe10.This model, named the Global surface temperature Spatial Forecast Model (GSFM) (Eq. (3)), operates as a patchwork, independently simulating inter-annual increments in surface temperature (ΔSST & ΔLAT) for each grid point and then amalgamating them to create a spatial distribution. The final predictions for the surface temperature distribution are derived by adding these increments to the current state10.Accordingly, we hindcast the spatial pattern of ΔSST & ΔLAT (Fig. 2d) in ENSO-year 2024, based on the observed values of the predictors. Subsequently, the prediction for the surface temperature anomalies in ENSO-year 2024 (Fig. 2c) is obtained by adding the increment (Fig. 2d) to the surface temperature anomalies in ENSO-year 2023. Model bias is defined as the difference between the GSFM prediction and observations (see Methods). Given that the modeled ΔGMST value of the GSFM is equal to that of the GMST forecast model, analyzing the spatial distribution of this bias (Fig. 2f) enables us to identify the potential causes of the GMST underestimation.During the 2023–24 El Niño, record-breaking temperatures were observed over extensive regions of the globe (Fig. 2a). In the tropical regions, these were mainly located in the Atlantic and the western Indian Ocean, as well as in the adjacent land areas. In extra-tropical regions, key areas of warming included the Eurasian continent, the northwest Pacific, and the northeastern part of North America.Statistically, based on the explained variance calculated for ENSO years from 1882 to 2023, the GSFM exhibits good predictive capabilities for tropical SSTs (Fig. 2e), largely due to ENSO teleconnections to these regions. In contrast, the GSFM has a relatively low explained variance in extratropical regions (Fig. 2e). Overall, the hindcast of surface temperature increment in the tropical oceans, Amazon and Alaska (Fig. 2d) were similar in pattern to the observations (Fig. 2b). The pattern correlation between the predicted SST & LAT with observed values is approximately 0.94, while the correlation for predicted and observed ΔSST & ΔLAT is 0.66. However, both the extent and intensity of the hindcast surface temperature anomalies are much weaker compared to the observations (Fig. 2b vs. 2d), aligning with the underestimation in GMST (Fig. 1a). This limitation is evident even in tropical oceans, including the western Indian Ocean and part of the tropical Atlantic, where observed SSTs were poorly captured despite the overall high explained variance by the model in these regions. In addition, over the tropical Atlantic, a large portion of the high SST area lies outside the region with high explained variance.One possible reason for this underestimation is that the GSFM demonstrates relatively low prediction proficiency in extratropical regions (Fig. 2e). For instance, the estimated SST anomalies over the subtropical North Pacific and North Atlantic are underestimated by the model (Fig. 2f). In these two regions, the GSFM simulated cooling (Fig. 2d) in contrast to the observed warming (Fig. 2b).Another possible explanation for this underestimation is that the TNINO index we use ref. 10 overlooks the diversity of ENSO and may therefore underestimate its global impact. Specifically, tropical Pacific SST anomalies during the 2023–24 El Niño exhibited a double-peak spatial structure over the central and eastern Pacific 2a). However, the TNINO index alone fails to capture this spatial structure, as shown by the comparison between Fig. 2a, c. This representation of tropical Pacific SSTs may lead to substantial underestimation of ENSO’s impacts, particularly in terms of its influence on SSTs across other tropical ocean basins25,26.Additionally, atmospheric internal variability is also a key factor contributing to the record-breaking GMST27,28. In particular, atmospheric internal variability in the extra-tropical Northern Hemisphere is recognized as the second largest source of GMST variability after ENSO29. However, for interannual predictions, atmospheric internal variability remains challenging to accurately capture, and so is the leading source of the disagreement between observations and predicted GMST. Therefore, here we primarily focus on tropical SSTs, as they are typically well-correlated with ENSO and exhibit higher predictability.Contributions of SST anomalies in various basins to GMSTGlobal surface temperature is closely tied to the state of SST2,30. The component of GMST variability originating from global or regional SST variability encompasses both the direct contribution from SST magnitude and the indirect contribution from SST-pattern effect30. As an integral component of GMST, a rise in SST (ΔSST) directly drives an increase in GMST (ΔGMST), reflecting the direct contribution from SST values. However, SST variations across different geographic regions influence LAT to varying degrees. In turn, the same magnitude of SST change in one region may have a different effect on GMST than in another region. This phenomenon is termed the SST-pattern effect30,31,32, which constitutes the indirect effect of SST on GMST.A Green’s Function (GF) approach enables us to quantify the component of interannual (or monthly) GMST variability originating from SST forcing at each grid point (Methods)23,30,33. The approach makes no assumptions about the causes of SST variability. For a given SST anomaly field, GF estimates its influence on GMST variability for the given month or year, regardless of whether that SST anomaly field is forced or natural. Following the definition from previous studies23,30,32, the GMST estimated from the SST field via the GF is designated as SST-correction.Following this definition, the SST-correction encapsulates both the direct contribution from the magnitude of SST anomalies and the indirect contribution from the SST-pattern effect. The former can be calculated through area weighting of SST. For example, weighted global or regional ΔSST is ΔSST adjusted by the percentage of global or regional ocean area relative to the global surface, ensuring proportional contributions. The residual, defined as the SST-pattern effect, is quantified by the difference between the SST-correction and weighted ΔSST, which captures the influence of ΔSST spatial configurations on LAT.Taking the observed ΔSST into the GF framework, the observed ΔGMST is well reconstructed by the global SST-correction (see Methods; Supplementary Fig. 7), with an RMSE of approximately 0.07 °C. This error amplitude is comparable to what is typically seen in the GMST forecast model (Fig. 1c). Unlike with the GMST forecast model (Eq. (1)), the record-breaking ΔGMST in ENSO-year 2024 can be calculated quite accurately (Fig. 3b & Supplementary Fig. 7). The SST-correction is 0.34 °C, with a bias of -0.02 °C, and the weighted global ΔSST is 0.18 °C. These values underscore the decisive role of SST.Fig. 3: Observed and GSFM modeled SST-correction.In (a), the observed ΔSST induced corrections to ΔGMST in ENSO-year 2024 are presented. In (b), SST-correction and weighted ΔSST of different oceans in ENSO-year 2024 from observations are displayed. The SST-pattern effect is quantified by the difference between the SST-correction (red bar) and weighted ΔSST (blue bar). c, d are similar to (a, b), but for the modeled ΔSST (shown in Fig. 2d). The black dots in (b) and (d) represent the observed ΔGMST. e, f illustrate the differences in SST-correction and weighted ΔSST between the observed and modeled ΔSST. The domains for the Indian Ocean (IO: 15°S–20°N, 40°E –120°E), the tropical Pacific (TP: 15°S–15°N, 150°E –90°W), and the tropical North Atlantic (TNA: 0°–30°N, 60°W –0°) are marked in (a). In the left column, the percentage accounted for in the observed ΔGMST is shown on the left-hand y-axis. SST-correction methods are detailed in Methods.Full size imageClearly, tropical SSTs contribute most to the ΔGMST (Fig. 3a). The sum of the SST-corrections across the tropical Pacific, Indian Ocean, and tropical North Atlantic regions reaches 0.29 °C, accounting for 80% of the observed ΔGMST (Fig. 3b).The ΔGMST value from the GSFM, which is equal to that of the GMST forecast model, can be partitioned into the ΔSST and ΔLAT components. The weighted global ΔSST from the GSFM is about 0.11 °C (Fig. 3d). Since the modeled ΔSST or ΔLAT for each grid point is simulated independently10, there is no specific manifestation for the SST-pattern effect from the modeled ΔSST pattern. Taking the modeled ΔSST (Fig. 2d) from the GSFM into the GF framework (Fig. 3c), the global SST-correction is 0.20 °C (Fig. 3d), which is 25% higher than our hindcast value of 0.16 °C but still below the observed 0.36 °Ç. This probably indicates that SST other than those closely related to ENSO (TNINO index) have an influence on LAT, and this influence is not strongly linked to TNINO index.The decisive role of SST in determining GMST suggests that accurate ΔSST from the GSFM output, combined with an SST correction from the GF framework, could potentially predict the record-breaking ΔGMST more accurately. Thus, the underestimated ΔSST is a key factor in the model’s underestimation of our previously published prediction of ΔGMST9. Next, we examine the discrepancies in SST-correction (Fig. 3e) derived from the modeled ΔSST (Fig. 2d) and the observed ΔSST (Fig. 2b) to determine which ocean basin’s ΔSST underestimation had the most notable impact.The most prominent negative difference is located in the tropical central Pacific (Fig. 3e), highlighting that the underestimation of ΔSST in this region has the most notable impact on ΔGMST. Concurrently, the overestimated SSTs in the broader tropical Pacific partially offset the negative contribution from the tropical central Pacific. Since the SSTs in the tropical Pacific are largely prescribed by the observed TNINO index, the regionally weighted ΔSST in the model shows minimal deviation from the observations. The substantial discrepancies in their SST corrections primarily arise from differences in their SST-pattern effects (Fig. 3f), which are associated with the spatial pattern of the El Niño, or El Niño diversity.Outside the tropical Pacific, the underestimation of ΔSST in the tropical North Atlantic (TNA) has the most notable impact on modeled ΔGMST (Fig. 3f). Generally, tropical SSTs are associated with El Niño and the GSFM demonstrates high prediction skill in these areas (Fig. 2e). Given the model’s severe underestimation of tropical SSTs in ENSO-year 2024 (Fig. 2f), we will next focus on analyzing the causes of abnormal warming in the tropical oceans from July 2023 to June 2024, especially for TNA.Linkage of El Niño to the warming across tropical ocean basinsThe 2023–24 El Niño event exhibited a distinctive two-step warming pattern with centers in both the eastern and central equatorial Pacific (Fig. 4a). The event began with warming signals in both the western and eastern equatorial Pacific early in 202334. The warming signal in the eastern equatorial Pacific greatly intensified through March and April, culminating in an extreme coastal El Niño event that peaked in April35,36. Following a brief weakening in May, a basin-scale El Niño emerged34. By October, a second warming center had formed in the central Pacific, leading to a steady increase in SST across the tropical Pacific (Fig. 4a).Fig. 4: Time-longitude diagram of SST and precipitation anomalies.a Time-longitude diagram for SST anomalies (shading; °C) and 28 °C isotherm (thick purple curve) along the equatorial Indian and Pacific Oceans (40°E–60°W, averaged over 15°S–15°N) and tropical North Atlantic (60°W–0°, averaged over 0°–30°N) for January 2023 to June 2024. b Time-longitude diagram for tropical precipitation anomalies (averaged over 5°S–5°N; mm day-1). c, d are the same as (a) and (b), but for a composite of El Niño years. The values for SST and precipitation doted in (c, d) are statistically significant at the 95% confidence level via Student’s t-test. To illustrate the month-to-month evolution during El Niño periods, the values are all detrended via a 10-year moving boxcar average. Case selection for composite analysis is described in Methods.Full size imageMeanwhile, the evolution of SST anomalies in the tropical Indian Ocean transitioned from an Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD)37,38 pattern in the boreal summer and autumn of 2023 to a basin-wide warming in early 2024 (Fig. 4a, b). These developments reflect a well-known response of the tropical Indian Ocean to El Niño in the Pacific (Fig. 4c, d)39. El Niño energizes the IOD by modulating the Walker circulation and generating easterly wind anomalies in the Indian Ocean, which generate IOD events, peaking from June to October25,26,31,34,40,41. Since the 1980s, the four extreme positive IOD events (1994, 1997, 2006, 2019) have all coincided with El Niño events25. However, these El Niño events exhibited distinct characteristics in their magnitude and spatial pattern in the tropical Pacific25. The 1997 extreme positive IOD coincided with an extreme El Niño, with its SST anomaly center located in the eastern Pacific, while the other three events were accompanied by moderate El Niño conditions with SST anomaly centers located in the central Pacific.The tropical Pacific in 2023 exhibited a double-peak SST structure, resembling the pattern observed in 200642,43. Numerical experiments show that, compared to the eastern Pacific, central Pacific SST warming more effectively drives easterly winds over the tropical Indian Ocean25. This suggests that the extreme IOD in 2023 may have been linked to the El Niño SST warming center in the central Pacific.From April to October, central Pacific convection (Fig. 4b) interacted with the seasonal window for thermocline feedback created by the climatological southeasterly winds off Sumatra, favoring IOD development (Fig. 4a)38,44. After October, weakening southeasterly winds suppressed the upwelling in the southeast, causing the IOD to weaken (Supplementary Fig. 8b). The zonal SST gradient in the Indian Ocean did not completely disappear, though, and a weak precipitation dipole was still visible in the boreal winter of 2024 (Fig. 4b).The SST warming in TNA can be divided into three phases. The first phase commenced at the beginning of 2023, preceding the development of El Niño (Fig. 4a). During this phase, the TNA warming persisted with a slight attenuation until October. There has been considerable discussion regarding its origins45,46,47,48,49 with the critical role of shortwave radiation highlighted in previous studies47,48,49. The second phase, characterized by rapid warming during the boreal winter of 2023-24, coincided with the peak phase of El Niño (marked by the black box in Fig. 4). The third phase, observed in the spring of 2024, reflected the typical delayed response to ENSO forcing during boreal winter (Fig. 4c)50,51. The substantial warming of TNA SST during the second phase in boreal winter however (Fig. 4a) represents a clear deviation from the typical relationship between ENSO and the TNA (Fig. 4c). Our subsequent analysis will concentrate on this warming phase in detail.A heat-budget analysis of the SST tendency (see Methods) reveals that the warming in TNA is primarily driven by atmospheric heat flux forcing (Fig. 5a). Specifically, reduced evaporation (\({Q}_{L}\) in Fig. 5a) and enhanced shortwave radiation (\({Q_{SW}}\) in Fig. 5a) are the main factors. An anomalous anticyclone over the TNA (contours in Fig. 5b) weakened the surface wind speed (blue vectors in Fig. 5b), thereby reducing the local evaporation. The persistent anticyclone also intensified incoming solar radiation. As a consequence, SST increased (Fig. 5b). These results are consistent with those of several other studies, which specifically focused on the drivers of the unprecedented North Atlantic SST warming at this time47,48,52 including a reduction in mixed layer depth, which would have increased the sensitivity of the surface layer to surface heat flux forcing48,52.Fig. 5: Mechanisms for the TNA SST warming coincided with the peak phase of El Niño in winter.a 15-day running mean time series of the tendencies in TNA (0–30°N, 50°W–10°W) SST anomalies (\(\frac{\partial {T}_{s}}{\partial t}\)) and the net surface heat flux (\({Q}_{{net}}\), positive downwards). \({Q}_{{net}}\) is comprised of surface net downward shortwave radiation (\({Q}_{{SW}}\)), surface net longwave radiation (\({Q}_{{LW}}\)), surface latent heat flux (\({Q}_{L}\)), and surface sensible heat flux (\({Q}_{S}\)). Anomalous December-February mean 200 hPa geopotential height (GPH; contour; gpm), SST (shading; °C), and 10 m wind (vector; m s−1; 0–60°N, 60°W–30°E) for (b) 2024 and (c) composite of El Niño years. In (b, c), the surface wind speed anomalies stronger (weaker) than the climatological winds are in red (blue). In (b,c), the positive and negative centers of GPH anomalies are noted by ‘H’ and ‘L’, respectively. Per thermal wind theory, this extension is primarily driven by the meridional temperature gradient (Supplementary Fig. 11), which correlates with the preceding SST warming patterns (Fig. 5b).An Earth’s energy imbalance (EEI) perspectiveFor the entire climate system, all energy entering or exiting the system is transferred via radiation at the top-of-atmosphere (TOA). The TOA energy budget is determined by the amount of incoming net absorbed shortwave (solar) radiation (ASR) and the outgoing longwave (thermal) radiation (OLR). The Earth’s Energy Imbalance (EEI) can be measured by net TOA radiation downward \({{{{\rm{R}}}}}_{{{{\rm{T}}}}}={{{\rm{ASR}}}}-{{{\rm{OLR}}}}\), which arises from multiple factors: forcing, feedback, and internal variability57.EEI causes heating of the planet, which is manifested in multiple ways, including ice melt, land warming, and a rise in ocean heat content (OHC). Changes in GMST on the other hand are related to surface temperatures (LAT and SST). Therefore, both GMST and EEI are influenced by the same factors in Eq. (1). It has been well understood that the accumulation of carbon dioxide reduces the amount of infrared radiation emitted to space, leading to planetary-scale energy accumulation58,59, while the anthropogenic and volcanic aerosols can cool the climate system by reflecting sunlight back to space. In addition, ENSO can cause year-to-year fluctuations in EEI49,60. Generally, during La Niña phases, the EEI increases, representing a net energy gain for the Earth system. By contrast, during El Niño phases, the EEI decreases, indicating a net energy loss from the system57,60,61. The cold and warm ENSO phases also correspond to the recharge and discharge of OHC, which in turn influences the variations in GMST60,61. Specifically, the ocean releases heat to the atmosphere during El Niño events primarily by elevated SST, making the extreme El Niño years like 1998 and 2016 relatively the warmest on record10,15,61.Given that 2023–24 El Niño was less intense than historic extremes, models based on Eq. (1) in Methods are incapable of hindcasting a ΔGMST that exceeds those during previous extreme El Niño. Furthermore, the results based on the GF framework help to identify the underestimated ΔSST as being a key factor contributing to the GSFM’s underestimation of ΔGMST. Analysis of the EEI enables us to track the heat sources behind the SST and GMST warming, providing additional insight into the GF results.OHC of the ocean surface layer \(({H}_{s})\) can be regarded as the main source of heating for GMST. To illustrate the relationship between the \({H}_{s}\) and the EEI, we consider a two-layer ocean model with the depth of the oceanic surface layer is set at 100 m49 and a deeper layer of depth Hd below it. Given that approximately 90% of the EEI is stored in the ocean58,62, the heat budget for the ocean is$$\frac{{dH}}{{dt}}=\frac{d{H}_{s}}{{dt}}+\frac{d{H}_{d}}{{dt}}\approx {R}_{T}$$where H = Hs + Hd. The first term (\(\frac{{dH}}{{dt}}\)) on the left represents the rate of change in the total OHC, including the changes in OHC of the surface layer (\(\frac{d{H}_{s}}{{dt}}\)) and the deep layer (\(\frac{d{H}_{d}}{{dt}}\)).It has been reported that three consecutive years of La Niña conditions contributed to an increase in RT49,57,59. An exceptional increase in EEI occurred between November 2022 and May 2023 before the 2023-24 El Niño49,59,63. Correspondingly, both RT and interannual OHC increment (ΔH) in ENSO-year 2023 reached record-breaking levels (Fig. 6a). This phenomenon is related to ocean currents and internal waves that change the thermocline depth, a relationship consistent with the tropical Pacific warming. Additionally, the increase in ASR, predominantly over the ocean63, further elevates the \({\Delta {{{\rm{H}}}}}_{{{{\rm{s}}}}}\) during ENSO-year 2024 (Fig. 6c), particularly as it relates to TNA SST warming47,48,49. Despite the increase in global surface temperature enhancing OLR, RT in ENSO-year 2024 remains positive. This indicates that the surface layer is simultaneously heated by both the deep ocean and the TOA, thereby leading to a surge in GMST49. Meanwhile, ENSO plays a crucial role in this energy distribution, particularly in the storage and release of OHC, as described in other studies18,49,59,63.Our analysis in this section puts the influence of ENSO on SST via adjustments in the vertical distribution of OHC prior to and during ENSO-year 2024 in the broader context of the EEI.DiscussionDuring the 2023–2024 El Niño event, the GMST in ENSO-year 2024 (July 2023 to June 2024) experienced an unprecedented 0.36 °C increase from the prior ENSO-year (July 2022 to June 2023), causing it to surpass the threshold of 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels (Fig. 1a).Our earlier published forecast of the GMST9 for ENSO-year 2024 indicated an upper boundary of the predictive range that was 0.12 °C lower than the observed value. We have identified that the primary reason for this underestimation lies in the inadequate valuation of both the SSTs themselves and the specific SST-pattern effect within our forecasting model. These shortcomings we have found in this study are related to the low predictability for extratropical regions and their inadequate representation of ENSO diversity.Based on the above analysis, integrating prior estimates of OHC may improve the prediction accuracy of the SST magnitude. For the SST-pattern effect, a potential improvement is to first forecast SST distribution using Eq. (1) (including prior OHC), then calculate the GMST with the GF. Validations of these approaches are deferred to future studies.Our results indicate that increased global SST during 2023–24 accounts for ~92% of the inter-annual increment in GMST (Fig. 3b). The 2023–24 El Niño with dual warming centers in the central and eastern tropical Pacific amplified GMST to a greater extent than typical El Niño events captured in our hindcast results. The spatiotemporal evolution characteristics of this El Niño event, combined with the eastward North Atlantic jet stream extension, contributed to greater SST increases in the tropical Indian Ocean and North Atlantic. From the perspective of EEI, the OHC accumulated during the preceding La Niña18,49 and the continuously enhanced ASR made substantial contributions to the subsequent rise in SST during the 2023–24 El Niño event.Several remaining issues emerge from these findings. First, while our analysis demonstrates that the SST-correction in the tropical Atlantic and Indian Oceans is related to ENSO, the GF methodology—based on temporally coincident variations—does not quantify the Pacific El Niño’s lagged impacts (e.g., seasonally delayed TNA warming and Indian Ocean basin mode development). Thus, the exact proportional contributions of ENSO versus other drivers (e.g., internal variability, anthropogenic forcing) to the extreme SSTs in these regions remain unclear.Second, and more fundamentally, the record-high TNA and Indian Ocean SSTs in 2023–24 did not scale linearly with the intensity of the El Niño47. Internal variability and anthropogenic forcing likely played a role in shaping this El Niño event’s atypical teleconnection patterns by preconditioning an eastward shift of the Atlantic jet stream, which subsequently amplified regional SST responses. This raises important questions about whether these exceptional teleconnections resulted purely from stochastic variability or reflected preconditioning by decadal variations in background states. Projecting whether similar atypical teleconnections will recur requires further investigation into how ENSO diversity interacts with anthropogenic warming and internal climate modes.Although we focus on the role of El Niño in this study, this does not preclude the contributions of other factors, such as declining anthropogenic aerosols64,65 and internal variability. For instance, the North Atlantic warming observed in early 2023 was particularly anomalous (Fig. 4a), as cooling in the TNA would typically be expected following the preceding La Niña event (Fig. 4c). This unusual warming may have been driven by the combined effects of anthropogenic forcing and internal variability30,45,46,47. Furthermore, the limited predictability of extratropical regions is closely tied to atmospheric internal variability28,66. Recently, the model results have suggested that the record-breaking SSTs observed over the North Pacific in 2023 are likely attributable mostly to internal variability27, other studies have indicated that the aerosol loading from East Asia may have contributed to the warming trend in both GMSTs and the North Pacific in the past decade67,68. It is assumed that, in Eq. (1), the radiative effects of other well-mixed greenhouse gases (excluding carbon dioxide) and anthropogenic aerosols largely offset one another15,69, with their overall impact being negligible. However, recent studies67,68 highlight the need to emphasize and investigate the decline in anthropogenic aerosol concentrations in future research.Moreover, while such abrupt interannual warming does not necessarily indicate a permanent breach of the Paris Agreement’s 1.5 °C threshold, it may trigger multiple climate tipping points6 and is a warning that the Earth is within range of entering a period of hazardous climate change8. items.title: L’orso bruno marsicano, una sottospecie unica
items.description:
Uno studio appena pubblicato dell’Università di Ferrara ha approfondito le caratteristiche genetiche dell'orso marsicano
The post L’orso bruno m
items.body: In evidenza WWF Italia: 60 anni per la natura In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Uno studio ne conferma l’unicità Uno studio appena pubblicato dell’Università di Ferrara ha approfondito le caratteristiche genetiche della residua popolazione di orso bruno marsicano, confrontando il genoma di questa sottospecie unica con quello di popolazioni di orso bruno in Europa centrale e Nordamerica. Per il WWF Italia, i risultati evidenziano ancora una volta l’unicità della nostra sottospecie appenninica, che convive con l’uomo nell’Italia centrale da millenni. Una sottospecie ad alto rischio Gli orsi bruni marsicani hanno mostrato una ridotta diversità genomica e un maggiore livello di consanguineità rispetto ad altre popolazioni di orso bruno, fattori che aumentano il rischio di estinzione per una popolazione selvatica sul medio-lungo termine. Lo studio ha rivelato, però, anche che la popolazione appenninica di orso, a differenza delle altre analizzate, possiede alcuni geni associati a una ridotta aggressività. Probabilmente la coesistenza con l’uomo nei millenni e la maggiore probabilità di sopravvivere e riprodursi degli individui particolarmente elusivi e non aggressivi hanno “selezionato” e “fissato” queste caratteristiche nell’orso bruno marsicano.I risultati della ricerca supportano l’ipotesi che l’adattamento al contesto antropizzato abbia dunque promosso cambiamenti comportamentali in una popolazione piccola e isolata da lungo tempo. Questa selezione ha portato nel corso dei secoli ad una riduzione dei conflitti e ha contribuito a diminuire i conflitti e a migliorare la coesistenza con l’uomo, aumentando le probabilità di sopravvivenza fino ad oggi di questa sottospecie unica. Un tassello fondamentale della nostra biodiversità L’orso bruno marsicano rappresenta una componente straordinaria del patrimonio naturale italiano, caratterizzato dunque da unicità genetica, ecologica e comportamentale maturata nel corso di millenni di isolamento nell’Appennino centrale.“Studi come questo testimoniano la peculiarità evolutiva del nostro orso gentile e l’importanza di preservarne l’integrità biologica- afferma Marco Antonelli, zoologo ed esperto di grandi carnivori per il WWF Italia-. Questa sottospecie è oggi classificata come a rischio critico di estinzione, con una popolazione stimata in poco più di 50 individui, una bassa variabilità genetica dovuta all’isolamento e molteplici minacce antropiche che ne mettono a rischio la sopravvivenza”.Investire nella conservazione dell’orso marsicano significa non solo proteggere un simbolo della biodiversità italiana, ma anche salvaguardare un pool genetico unico e un ruolo ecologico insostituibile negli ecosistemi dell’Appennino. Sono sempre più urgenti sforzi concreti per mitigare le minacce e permettere l’incremento numerico e l’espansione spaziale della popolazione anche in altre aree nell’Appennino centro-meridionale. Foto HomoAmbiens Questo Natale, regalando l’adozione WWF di un orso bruno marsicano , si sosterrà il progetto Orso 2×50, che mira a raddoppiare l’areale della sottospecie di orso bruno marsicano e il numero di individui presenti entro il 2050. Il WWF Italia lavora da anni per creare una cintura di sicurezza intorno alle zone in cui vive l’orso, ripristinando sottopassi stradali abbandonati e impraticabili per gli animali, distribuendo nuove recinzioni a tutela degli allevamenti, installando dissuasori acustici e ottici che scoraggino gli orsi ad attraversare le strade più pericolose, favorendo la convivenza con le popolazioni locali. Ognuno può fare la sua piccola parte per salvare l’orso gentile dei nostri appennini. Orso bruno marsicano Sostieni i progetti WWF in difesa dell'orso bruno marsicano Aderisci all'appello Orso 2x50 Per garantire un futuro all'orso bruno marsicano, il WWF ha lanciato a tutti gli attori presenti sul territorio (Comuni, Regioni, Aree Protette, Enti Scientifici e Associazioni) una ambiziosa sfida di conservazione con il progetto Orso 2x50, con l’obiettivo di raddoppiare l’areale della specie e il numero di individui presenti entro il 2050 . items.title: Agroecologia, l’Italia taglia i fondi per la ricerca del programma europeo
items.description:
L’Italia ha deciso di sospendere il cofinanziamento per l’Agroecology Partnership e gli enti ed istituti di ricerca del nostro Paese
The post Agroecol
items.body: In evidenza WWF Italia: 60 anni per la natura In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Si chiama Agroecology Partnership (“European Partnership on accelerating farming systems transition through agroecology”) l’iniziativa cofinanziata del Cluster 6 di Horizon Europe, avviata nel biennio 2023–2024 con l’obiettivo di accelerare la transizione verso sistemi agricoli più resilienti, sostenibili e fondati sulla biodiversità. Uno strumento importante per l’agroecologia L’Agroecology Partnership rappresenta uno dei principali strumenti europei a sostegno della ricerca e dell’innovazione in ambito agroecologico, coinvolgendo Stati Membri, enti di ricerca, imprese, organizzazioni della società civile, reti di Living Lab e infrastrutture scientifiche impegnate nella gestione sostenibile delle risorse genetiche. Queste partnership cofinanziate prevedono un modello di finanziamento congiunto in cui la Commissione Europea copre circa il 30% dei costi, mentre ciascuno Stato membro è tenuto a garantire la propria quota nazionale, quale condizione indispensabile per rendere eleggibili i beneficiari ai bandi. Lo strappo dell’Italia L’Italia ha deciso di sospendere il cofinanziamento per l’Agroecology Partnership e gli enti ed istituti di ricerca del nostro Paese potenzialmente beneficiari saranno automaticamente esclusi dall’accesso ai fondi comunitari nei prossimi bandi. In Italia la partecipazione all’Agroecology Partnership è di competenza congiunta del Ministero dell’Università e della Ricerca (MUR) e del Ministero dell’Agricoltura , Sovranità Alimentare e Foreste (MASAF). A differenza di quanto avvenuto per altre partnership del Cluster 6 – come Biodiversa+, alla quale l’Italia partecipa con contributi pluriennali già definiti – per Agroecology Partnership i documenti ufficiali indicano che non è stato previsto alcun finanziamento nazionale per i bandi 2025/2026. Gli altri Stati membri che partecipano alla Partnership – tra cui Francia, Germania, Paesi Bassi e Paesi scandinavi – hanno fin dall’inizio assicurato un impegno finanziario pluriennale stabile, garantendo piena continuità ai propri beneficiari. Il quadro regolatorio di Horizon Europe richiede infatti agli Stati una dimostrazione di impegno a lungo termine e una conferma annuale della partecipazione, necessarie per mantenere un ruolo attivo nella Partnership e nei processi decisionali strategici. Un problema per la competitività e per tutto il settore La decisione del nostro Governo di sospendere il cofinanziamento rischia di compromettere attività già consolidate e pienamente integrate nella rete agroecologica europea, con ricadute significative sulla competitività del settore agroalimentare nazionale. Una mancata adesione reiterata potrebbe marginalizzare il nostro Paese, ridurne l’influenza nella governance del programma europeo Horizon e limitare il contributo italiano alla transizione agroecologica. La lettera delle Associazioni Queste preoccupazioni sono state espresse dai Presidenti di quattro Associazioni nazionali (AIDA – Associazione Italiana di Agroecologia, Lipu, Rete Semi Rurali e WWF Italia) con una lettera inviata al Ministero dell’agricoltura, MASAF, ritenuto il  principale responsabile della sospensione del cofinanziamento da parte dell’Italia, chiedendo chiarimenti sulle ragioni di questo disimpegno per l’annualità 2025/2026 e garanzie per il futuro sostegno all’Agroecology Partnership. Le quattro Associazioni chiedono quali siano le motivazioni della mancata dotazione finanziaria, considerando il forte interesse manifestato dal nostro Paese e l’attiva partecipazione di numerosi enti e istituti di ricerca italiani alla rete agroecologica europea. Alla lettera inviata dalle Associazioni hanno fatto riferimento anche i parlamentari, Zanella e Borrelli, che hanno depositato una interrogazione scritta rivolta al Ministro dell’agricoltura, Francesco Lollobrigida, per chiedere quali iniziative intenda assumere per garantire la continuità della partecipazione dell’Italia alle future annualità della Partnership, assicurando così ai soggetti italiani l’accesso ai bandi e il mantenimento del ruolo strategico del nostro Paese nella governance europea della ricerca in agroecologia. L’auspicio è che il mancato cofinanziamento dell’Agroecology Partnership rappresenti solo un incidente di percorso con effetti temporanei e non l’indicatore di un completo abbandono del nostro Paese dell’investimento nella ricerca scientifica per la promozione di sistemi agroalimentari più sostenibili e resilienti. 27 Luglio 2021 Agroecologia per la sostenibilità L'agroecologia garantisce equa alimentazione per tutti e benessere del Pianeta Giulia Ciarlariello 23 Gennaio 2020 Cambiamo agricoltura con una PAC più verde Dal Convegno “PAC post 2020: verso il Piano Strategico Nazionale”, che si è svolto oggi a Roma presso lo Spazio Europa gestito dall’Ufficio del Parlamento europeo e dalla Rappresentanza della Commissione Europea in Italia, le Associazioni ambientaliste e… 29 Febbraio 2024 23 Associazioni scrivono al ministro Lollobrigida 23 Associazioni hanno inviato una lettera al Ministro dell’agricoltura, Francesco Lollobrigida, per chiedere un confronto sul futuro dell’agricoltura e dei sistemi agro-alimentari 6 Maggio 2025 Agricoltura rigenerativa: WWF, rigenerare il suolo per salvare l'agricoltura La visione del WWF dell’agricoltura rigenerativa per una giusta transizione ecologica dei sistemi agroalimentari

items.title: EBA Statistical Report 2025: continua la crescita del biogas in Europa
items.description: EBA, l’Associazione europea del biogas, di cui il CIB è parte, ha pubblicato in questi giorni la nuova edizione dello Statistical Report, il documento
items.body:
EBA Statistical Report 2025: continua la crescita del biogas in Europa

11 Dicembre 2025

EBA, l’Associazione europea del biogas, di cui il CIB è parte, ha pubblicato in questi giorni la nuova edizione dello Statistical Report, il documento che fotografa ogni anno la situazione del settore del biogas e del biometano in Europa. Il rapporto sottolinea l’urgente necessità di potenziare le soluzioni nazionali basate sul gas rinnovabile. Il biogas offre una via diretta per ridurre la dipendenza energetica strategica, aumentando al contempo la competitività dell’Europa nella sua ambizione di eliminare gradualmente i combustibili fossili.  l’EBA Statistical Report 2025, rivela ancora una volta una crescita della produzione di biogas e biometano (22 miliardi di metri cubi nel 2024, rispetto ai 21,7 miliardi di metri cubi del 2023), concentrata principalmente nei paesi dell’UE-27 (19 miliardi di metri cubi). Il biometano continua a essere il segmento in più rapida crescita (5,2 miliardi di metri cubi, di cui 4,3 prodotti nell’UE-27), sostenuto da una capacità installata di 7 miliardi di metri cubi all’anno in Europa entro l’inizio del 2025.Inoltre, nel 2024 l’Europa ha prodotto 25 Mt (DM) di digestato. Il suo ruolo consolidato come ammendante e fertilizzante organico si sta espandendo, con nuovi percorsi di valorizzazione che stanno guadagnando slancio.Il rapporto completo è acquistabile sul sito di EBA ed è possibile rivedere il webinar di presentazione ai seguenti link.Consulta il comunicato stampaGuarda la registrazione del webinarGuarda le slide del webinarAcquista il rapporto completo (non soci)

items.title: Una sfida difficile ma non rinviabile
items.description: Pochi mesi fa, nella primavera 2025, il fisico Antonello Pasini, ricercatore Cnr e noto divulgatore, oltre che animatore del comitato La Scienza al Vo
items.body:
Una sfida difficile ma non rinviabile                
												
																																	                
					Dic 5, 2025Dic 5, 2025

Pochi mesi fa, nella primavera 2025, il fisico Antonello Pasini, ricercatore Cnr e noto divulgatore, oltre che animatore del comitato La Scienza al Voto, ha dato alle stampe un agile volumetto di 163 pagine intitolato “La sfida climatica. Dalla scienza alla politica: ragioni per il cambiamento” (Codice Edizioni, 2025, 18€).

Nel libro l’autore affronta, in ogni capitolo e in rapida sequenza, le diverse sfaccettature della sfida complessa che ci troviamo a fronteggiare: nel primo capitolo si discute della sfida scientifica e conoscitiva, nel secondo di quella filosofica e della visione del mondo, nel terzo di quella comunicativa, con alcune proposte e soluzioni, e nel quarto di quella politica. Un quinto capitolo, infine, è dedicato alla sfida forse più difficile, quella delle azioni da intraprendere per fronteggiare la crisi climatica.

Il tema scientifico occupa buona parte del libro, 64 pagine in cui Pasini affronta il difficile compito di riassumere la questione climatica odierna in termini comprensibili a chiunque, presentando una panoramica rigorosa e accessibile del fenomeno del cambiamento climatico, smontando luoghi comuni (“Il clima è sempre cambiato”, “Siamo troppo piccoli per influenzare il clima”) e sottolineando l’importanza di una solida conoscenza scientifica come base per le azioni. Non si tratta però di un’esposizione di tipo didattico, quanto piuttosto di una discussione di alcuni aspetti controversi, come per esempio il tema dell’attribuzione degli eventi estremi cui assistiamo con sempre maggior frequenza (ultima in Italia l’alluvione e la frana in Friuli del 17 novembre 2025); eventi attribuiti sempre più spesso non al caso, ma alle responsabilità di “Homo fossilis”, emettitore di enormi quantità di carbonio estratto dal sottosuolo e incessantemente bruciato in motori, caldaie e forni.

Nel capitolo “filosofico” (virgolette dell’autore) si affronta molto brevemente un tema in effetti enorme, quello del rapporto tra umanità e natura; o, meglio, della visione che l’uomo ha di se stesso come “dominatore del creato”, da sostituire con un approccio antitetico, dato che, come scrive Pasini, “i cambiamenti climatici ci mostrano un mondo diverso da quello che per lungo tempo abbiamo immaginato. Per adattarci a questo nuovo mondo, avremo bisogno di rivedere il nostro rapporto con gli ecosistemi, con gli esseri che li abitano e con i fenomeni inanimati che li pervadono. Avremo bisogno di un cambiamento filosofico, che parte e si intreccia con la conoscenza scientifica”. Si tratta di un programma davvero vasto che non sembra facile da perseguire, visto che in quasi ogni angolo del mondo già ai bambini si inculca il concetto che profitto e soldi sono le cose che più contano nella vita. In ogni caso, la tematica del cambio di paradigma filosofico si intreccia con quella  della comunicazione, anch’essa vastissima, che viene affrontata nel terzo capitolo.

Qui Pasini tocca diverse corde care ai frequentatori di Climalteranti, per esempio la diffusione sempre più pervasiva di disinformazione scientifica sul clima, in particolare sul web e sui social media, lo spazio sempre molto limitato e frammentario che i media più tradizionali dedicano alla questione climatica, la polarizzazione delle opinioni, che tende a prevalere persino sula formazione scientifica dei cittadini e che impedisce di rendersi conto della fondatezza fattuale delle opinioni altrui. Su questa tematica cruciale Pasini produce tre proposte di azione, la prima consiste nel “far parlare i due emisferi cerebrali” ovvero comunicare sia alla sfera razionale che a quella emotiva delle persone, contaminando la comunicazione scientifica con altri linguaggi, per esempio arte musica o teatro, insistere con i media perché si eviti il termine “maltempo” quando si descrivono eventi estremi causati dal nuovo clima, e anzi si faccia sempre menzione della causa primaria di ciò che sta accadendo, ovvero l’emissione continua di enormi quantità di carbonio fossile in atmosfera, infine comunicare la scienza del clima, insieme ai suoi metodi, senza tensioni muscolari ma “rispettando i valori di tutti” e condividendo le angosce e preoccupazioni che ognuno di noi prova quando si confronta col presente e col futuro.

Più in generale il libro si mostra anche come una sorta di sintetica spiegazione di quanto Pasini stesso stia cercando di fare, al di là delle sue importanti ricerche, per arrivare a istituzionalizzare in Italia il rapporto tra politica e scienza del clima. Come si diceva all’inizio, infatti, da ormai sette anni l’autore anima un gruppo piuttosto folto di studiosi denominato collettivamente comitato La scienza al voto, che ha prodotto, in particolare prima delle più importanti tornate elettorali, diversi “manifesti” e petizioni alla politica perché prenda sul serio, e in modo trasversale, la questione climatica, basandosi sulle risultanze scientifiche; e non affidandosi a primo che capita, purché dica quel che il politico di turno desidera sentirsi dire.

Più di recente Pasini ha promosso la creazione anche in Italia di un comitato consultivo permanente e ufficiale, denominato CSCA (Consiglio scientifico clima e ambiente), composto da studiosi selezionati non dalla politica ma dal mondo scientifico stesso, in ottemperanza alla recente Legge europea sul clima, che propugna l’istituzione di queste strutture sia a scala europea che nazionale.

Tornando al libro, va detto che, nonostante la sua brevità, risulta impegnativo per il lettore, dato che affronta diverse questioni complesse: dalla scienza alla comunicazione, alla politica, fino all’azione pratica. Il suo punto di forza è la capacità di Pasini di unire il rigore scientifico alla chiarezza divulgativa, offrendo un percorso che va dall’analisi dei processi in atto allo sviluppo di possibili soluzioni. Non si limita a gridare all’allarme, ma costruisce un ragionamento robusto che chiama in causa scienziati, cittadini e politici, evidenziando che l’unica incertezza non è più la crisi in sé, ma la nostra risposta. È una lettura essenziale per acquisire una maggiore consapevolezza della portata trasversale della crisi climatica e delle azioni urgenti che tutti siamo chiamati a compiere, individualmente e collettivamente. Potrà quindi essere apprezzato anche dagli “esperti” dei diversi rami perché possano ragionare “out of the box” e cogliere questioni di cui di solito non si occupano. Sicuramente una sfida anche questa, per riprendere il titolo.

Testo di Vittorio Marletto e Claudio Cassardo

items.title: Report BIP: digestato e biogas agricolo leve strategiche della bioeconomia circolare
items.description: Lo scorso 2 dicembre, nel corso di un recente evento tenutosi a Bruxelles, sono stati presentati i nuovi dati relativi alla produzione europea di biog
items.body:
Report BIP: digestato e biogas agricolo leve strategiche della bioeconomia circolare

5 Dicembre 2025

Lo scorso 2 dicembre, nel corso di un recente evento tenutosi a Bruxelles, sono stati presentati i nuovi dati relativi alla produzione europea di biogas e alla valorizzazione del digestato. L’analisi, illustrata da Piero Gattoni, Presidente dell’European Biogas Association (EBA) e del CIB – Consorzio Italiano Biogas, ha evidenziato un cambiamento strutturale nel settore: negli ultimi dodici anni la produzione di biogas è triplicata, confermando il ruolo strategico dell’agricoltura nella transizione energetica dell’Unione Europea.Al centro del dibattito non vi è solo la produzione energetica, ma l’affermazione di un modello di economia circolare ormai sistemico. Come emerge anche dal report “Use and Valorisation of Digestates: A Practical Review“ pubblicato dalla Biomethane Industrial Partnership (BIP), il digestato rappresenta una risorsa chiave in questo processo. Residuo del processo di digestione anaerobica, il digestato è un materiale organico arricchito di nutrienti che, restituito ai suoli, permette di chiudere il ciclo biologico delle aziende agricole.L’utilizzo agronomico del digestato offre una valida alternativa ai fertilizzanti di origine fossile, riducendo la dipendenza da processi produttivi energivori e contribuendo alla sicurezza degli approvvigionamenti. Inoltre, l’applicazione al suolo di questa materia organica stabilizzata favorisce lo stoccaggio di carbonio organico, mitigando le emissioni e migliorando la fertilità dei terreni.L’integrazione delle filiere, l’uso di tecnologie di precisione e il riutilizzo della CO₂ biogenica dimostrano come il biogas sia una leva concreta della bioeconomia. Il quadro che emerge è quello di un’agricoltura europea capace di generare energia rinnovabile, rigenerare i suoli e contribuire attivamente alla decarbonizzazione. Affinché questa trasformazione possa accelerare e consolidarsi, il settore richiede ora una visione politica stabile e un quadro normativo chiaro per il futuro.I contenuti del reportCapitolo 1Produzione europea di digestato: di cosa stiamo parlando?Come la digestione anaerobica influisce sulle proprietà del digestato?Caratteristiche del digestato intero (tal quale)Uso attuale dei digestati non trattatiCapitolo 2 Buone pratiche e principi europei per un uso diretto sicuro ed efficace dei digestati in agricolturaRidurre le emissioni di ammoniaca e metano e la lisciviazione dei nitratiSeparazione delle frazioni liquida e solida del digestatoApplicazione e stoccaggio della frazione liquida del digestatoApplicazione e stoccaggio della frazione solida del digestatoCapitolo 3Dal digestato ai fertilizzanti avanzati a base di digestatoBuone pratiche per prodotti fertilizzanti a base di digestato più avanzati/trattatiBarriere tecniche allo sviluppo di prodotti fertilizzanti a base di digestatoCapitolo 4 Portare sul mercato europeo fertilizzanti a base di digestato più avanzati/trattatiModelli di business per impianti di biogas con digestatiIl ruolo della regolamentazione e del sostegno politico per l’emergere della fertilizzazione organica in Europa
